Name: Report on staff misconduct at the department of correction.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to a report on staff misconduct at the department of correction

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Criminal Justice

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Correction (“DOC”), the Department of Investigation (“DOI”), the Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings (“OATH”), and the Board of Correction (“BOC”) to issue reports regarding staff misconduct cases against DOC employees. DOC and DOI would be required to report on closed staff misconduct cases from the past 10 years. DOC and OATH would also be required to issue a monthly report on open cases and a monthly report on cases closed in the previous month. DOI would be required to issue a quarterly report on cases closed in the previous quarter. BOC would be required to issue a quarterly report on staff misconduct cases that they referred to DOC, DOI, a district attorney, or the Department of Justice.

Be it enacted by the Council as follows:\ulnone\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\qj\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Section 1. Section 626 of the New York city charter is amended by adding a new subdivision i to read as follows:\par
\ul i. No later than 60 days after the effective date of the local law that added this subdivision, and quarterly thereafter, the board shall submit to the mayor and the speaker of the council and shall post conspicuously on the board\rquote s website a quarterly report regarding cases involving staff misconduct at the department of correction that the board referred for further investigation. Such report must include a table in which each separate row references a unique investigation. Each such row must include the following information, as well as any additional information the board deems appropriate, set forth in separate columns:\par
1. The category of any alleged misconduct offenses;\par
2. A description of the alleged staff misconduct and the procedural history of the staff misconduct case; and\par
3. Whether the case was referred to the department of correction, the department of investigation, a district attorney, or the United States department of justice. \par
\ulnone\'a7 2. Chapter 1 of title 9 of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 9-163 to read as follows:\par
\ul\'a7 9-163 Staff misconduct report. a. No later than 75 days after the effective date of the local law that added this section, the commissioner shall submit to the mayor and the speaker of the council and shall post conspicuously on the department\rquote s website a report regarding staff misconduct cases that were closed within 10 years preceding the effective date of the local law that added this section. Such report must include a table in which each separate row references a unique staff misconduct case. Each such row must include the following information for each staff misconduct case, as well as any additional information the commissioner deems appropriate, set forth in separate columns:\par
1. Any unique identifier used by the department to identify the staff misconduct case such as the case number;\par
\pard\ltrpar\li720\sl480\slmult1\qj 2. The date of the incident or incidents of alleged staff misconduct;\par
3. Each facility where the alleged staff misconduct occurred; \par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj 4. The date the staff misconduct case was initiated by the department;\par
5. The employee\rquote s last name;\par
6. The employee\rquote s shield number, if applicable;\par
7. The employee\rquote s civil service title;\par
8. The category of any alleged misconduct offenses;\par
9. A description of the alleged staff misconduct and the procedural history of the staff misconduct case;\par
10. If the case was adjudicated by the office of administrative trials and hearings, the date on which the case was referred to the office of administrative trials and hearings;\par
11. The execution date of the negotiated plea agreement; \par
12. The date the case was closed;\par
13. The disposition of the case;\par
14. The penalty and discipline imposed if any;\par
15. Whether the case was referred to the department of investigation, a district attorney, or the United States department of justice;\par
16. The number of previous staff misconduct cases associated with the employee; and\par
17. The case number, or other unique identifier used by the department to identify staff misconduct cases, of any previous staff misconduct cases associated with the employee.\par
b. No later than 60 days after effective date of the local law that added this section, and monthly thereafter, the commissioner shall submit to the mayor and the speaker of the council and shall post conspicuously on the department\rquote s website a report regarding open staff misconduct cases. Such report must include a table in which each separate row references a unique staff misconduct case. Each such row must include the following information and any additional information the commissioner deems appropriate, set forth in separate columns:\par
1. Any unique identifier used by the department to identify the staff misconduct case such as the case number;\par
\pard\ltrpar\li720\sl480\slmult1\qj 2. The date of the incident or incidents of alleged staff misconduct;\par
3. Each facility where the alleged staff misconduct occurred; \par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj 4. The date the staff misconduct case was initiated by the department;\par
5. The employee\rquote s last name;\par
6. The employee\rquote s shield number, if applicable;\par
7. The employee\rquote s civil service title;\par
8. The category of any alleged misconduct offenses;\par
9. A description of the alleged staff misconduct and the procedural history of the staff misconduct case;\par
10. If the case is being adjudicated by the office of administrative trials and hearings, the date on which the case was referred to the office of administrative trials and hearings;\par
11. The status of the case as of the date of the report; and\par
12. Whether the case was referred to the department of investigation, a district attorney, or the United States department of justice.\par
c. No later than 120 days after the effective date of the local law that added this section, and monthly thereafter, the commissioner shall submit to the mayor and the speaker of the council and shall post conspicuously on the department\rquote s website a report regarding staff misconduct cases against department employees that were closed in the previous month. Such report must include a table in which each separate row references a unique staff misconduct case. Each such row must include the following information, as well as any additional information the commissioner deems appropriate, set forth in separate columns:\par
1. Any unique identifier used by the department to identify the staff misconduct case such as the case number;\par
2. The date of the incident or incidents of alleged staff misconduct;\par
3. Each facility where the alleged staff misconduct occurred; \par
4. The date the staff misconduct case was initiated by the department;\par
5. The employee\rquote s last name;\par
6. The employee\rquote s shield number, if applicable;\par
7. The employee\rquote s civil service title;\par
8. The category of any alleged misconduct offenses;\par
9. A description of the alleged staff misconduct and the procedural history of the staff misconduct case;\par
10. If the case was adjudicated by the office of administrative trials and hearings, the date on which the case was referred to the office of administrative trials and hearings;\par
11. The execution date of the negotiated plea agreement; \par
12. The date the case was closed;\par
13. The disposition of the case;\par
14. The penalty and discipline imposed if any;\par
15. Whether the case was referred to the department of investigation, a district attorney, or the United States department of justice;\par
16. The number of previous staff misconduct cases associated with the employee; and\par
17. The case number, or other unique identifier used by the department to identify staff misconduct cases, of any previous staff misconduct cases associated with the employee.\par
d. No later than 60 days after the effective date of the local law that added this section, and monthly thereafter, the chief administrative law judge of the office of administrative trials and hearings shall submit to the mayor and the speaker of the council and shall post conspicuously on the office of administrative trials and hearings\rquote  website a report regarding open staff misconduct cases against department of correction employees. Such report must include a table in which each separate row references a unique staff misconduct case. Each such row must include the following information, as well as any additional information the chief administrative law judge deems appropriate, set forth in separate columns:\par
1. Any unique identifier used by the department of correction to identify the staff misconduct case such as the case number;\par
2. Any unique identifier used by the office of administrative trials and hearings to identify the staff misconduct case such as the case number;\par
3. The date of the incident or incidents of alleged staff misconduct;\par
4. Each facility where the alleged staff misconduct occurred;\par
5. The employee\rquote s last name;\par
6. The employee\rquote s shield number, if applicable;\par
7. The employee\rquote s civil service title;\par
8. The category of any alleged misconduct offenses;\par
9. A description of the alleged staff misconduct and the procedural history of the staff misconduct case;\par
10. The date on which the case was referred to the office of administrative trials and hearings; and\par
11. The status of the case as of the date of the report.\par
e. The reports required by subdivisions a, b, c, and d of this section shall include a data dictionary and glossary of terms.\par
\ulnone\'a7 3. Chapter 2 of title 33 of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 33-202 to read as follows:\par
\ul\'a7 33-202 Staff misconduct at the department of correction. a. No later than 75 days after the effective date of the local law that added this section, the commissioner shall submit to the mayor and the speaker of the council and shall post conspicuously on the department\rquote s website a report regarding cases involving staff misconduct at the department of correction that were closed within 10 years preceding the effective date of the local law that added this section. The report must include the total number of department of correction staff misconduct cases closed by the department, disaggregated by year and further disaggregated by:\par
1. The facility where the alleged staff misconduct occurred;\par
2. The employee\rquote s civil service title;\par
3. The category of any alleged misconduct offenses;\par
4. Whether the case was closed:\par
(a) Within 90 days;\par
(b) Between 91 days and 180 days;\par
(c) Between 181 days and 270 days;\par
(d) Between 271 days and 365 days; or \par
(e) More than 365 days after the case was initiated by the department;\par
5. The disposition of the case;\par
6. The penalty and discipline imposed if any;\par
7. Whether the case was referred to a district attorney; and\par
8. Whether the case was referred to the United States department of justice.\par
b. No later than 120 days after effective date of the local law that added this section, and quarterly thereafter, the commissioner shall submit to the mayor and the speaker of the council and shall post conspicuously on the department\rquote s website a report regarding cases involving staff misconduct at the department of correction that were closed in the previous quarter. The report must include the total number of department of correction staff misconduct cases closed by the department, disaggregated by:\par
1. The facility where the alleged staff misconduct occurred;\par
2. The employee\rquote s civil service title;\par
3. The category of any alleged misconduct offenses;\par
4. Whether the case was closed:\par
(a) Within 90 days;\par
(b) Between 91 days and 180 days;\par
(c) Between 181 days and 270 days;\par
(d) Between 271 days and 365 days; or \par
(e) More than 365 days after the case was initiated by the department;\par
5. The disposition of the case;\par
6. The penalty and discipline imposed if any;\par
7. Whether the case was referred to a district attorney; and\par
8. Whether the case was referred to the United States department of justice.\par
c. The reports required by subdivisions a and b of this section shall include a data dictionary and glossary of terms.\par
\ulnone\'a7 4. This local law takes effect immediately. \par
